# The Isochronicles: This First Law Saga Is a Gas

::: {style="text-align: center;"}
DOFPro Team
:::

![](../../DOFPro_D7_Black_Red_Flame_No_Background_Cropped.png){.absolute left="22%" top="-65%"}

## Introduction

1^st^ Law behavior for *Ideal Gases* for:

- Isothermal Process
- Isobaric Process
- Isochoric Process
- Isentropic Process

##

Equations and concepts for dealing with ideal gases in first law problems
</br></br>
**First:** heat capacity doesnâ€™t vary with pressure for ideal gases, only with temperature.

$$d\hat{U} = C_v dT,\hspace{120px} \Delta \hat{U} = \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2} C_v dT$$

$$d\hat{H} = C_p dT,\hspace{120px} \Delta \hat{H} = \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2} C_p dT$$

::: {.absolute top=80% left=23%}
$$C_p = C_v + R$$
:::

##

**Second:** for a closed system with ideal gas and no change in kinetic or potential energy.

$$d\hat{U} = \frac{dQ}{n} + \frac{dW}{n}$$

$$C_v dT = \frac{dQ}{n} - Pd\hat{V}$$

$$dQ = nC_v dT + PdV = nC_v dT + nRT \frac{dV}{V}$$

$$dQ = nC_p dT - nRT \frac{dP}{P}$$

## 

**Isothermal (Constant Temperature) Process:**

$$d\hat{U} = d\hat{H} = 0$$

$$dQ = dQ$$

$$dQ = n C_v dT + nRT \frac{dV}{V} = n C_P dT - nRT \frac{dP}{P}$$

$$Q = -W = nRT \ln \frac{V_2}{V_1} = nRT \ln \frac{P_1}{P_2}$$

<center>Note the order of the subscripts on $V$ and $P$.</center>

## 

**Isobaric (Constant Pressure) Process:**

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width=50%}

$$d\hat{U} = C_v dT$$
</br>
$$dW = -PdV$$
</br>
$$\Delta U = Q + W = Q - P \Delta V$$
</br>
$$\Delta U + P \Delta V = Q$$
:::
::: {.column width=50%}

$$Q = \Delta H = n \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2}C_p dT$$


$$\Delta \hat{U} = \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2}C_v dT$$

\begin{align}
W &= -P(V_2 - V_1)
\\
\\&= -nRT(T_2 - T_1)
\end{align}

:::
::::

## 

**Isochoric (Constant Volume) Process:**

$$dW = -PdV$$
</br>
$$d \hat{U} = C_V dT$$
</br>
$$Q = \Delta U = n \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2}C_v dT$$

##

**Adiabatic Reversible (Isentropic) Process:**

$$dQ = n C_v dT + P dV = n C_V dT + nRT \frac{dV}{V}$$

$$n C_v dT = -nRT \frac{dV}{V}$$

$$\frac{dT}{T} = - \frac{R}{C_v} \frac{dV}{V}$$

If $C_v = \mathrm{constant}$

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width=34%}
$$\ln \frac{T_2}{T_1} = \frac{R}{C_v} \ln \frac{V_1}{V_2}$$
:::
::: {.column width=33%}
$$\frac{T_2}{T_1} = \left(\frac{V_1}{V_2}\right)^{\frac{R}{C_v}}$$
:::
::: {.column width=33%}
$$\frac{T_2}{T_1} = \left(\frac{P_2}{P_1}\right)^{\frac{R}{C_v}}$$
:::
::::
<center>Note the order of the subscripts on $V$ and $P$.</center>

## The Takeaways

1. The Internal Energy ($U$), Enthalpy ($H$), and Heat Capacity ($C_v,\ C_p$) of an ideal gas are functions of temperature only, not pressure.
2. We developed the relationship among $Q$, $W$, $T$, $(V_2/V_1)$, and $(P_1/P_2)$ for an isothermal process for an ideal gas.
3. We developed the relationship among $Q$, $W$, $\Delta U$, $\Delta H$, $T$, $V$, and $P$ for an isobaric process for an ideal gas.
4. We developed the relationship between $Q$ and $\Delta U$ for an isochoric process for an ideal gas.
5. We developed the relationship among $W$, $(T_2/T_1)$, $(V_1/V_2)$, and $(P_2/P_1)$ for an isentropic process for an ideal gas.
